title: Appointing a backup wife
vignette: If the chief community elder's wife dies during his week of separation before Day of Atonement, should a second wife be prepared in advance?

options.text: Yes; arrange a potential wife to ensure ritual completeness.
No; preparing another spouse is unnecessary and awkward.

title: Keeping the chief community elder awake
vignette: Attendants sing and snap fingers all night so the chief community elder doesn't sleep before Day of Atonement. Is this required?

options.text: Yes; preventing sleep avoids ritual contamination from a nightly bodily fluid release.
Let him rest; fatigue could hinder the service.

title: Ritual Bath after accidental contamination
vignette: The chief community elder touches an insect by mistake during the service. Should he ritual bath again and restart preparations?

options.text: ritual bath immediately and resume once uncontaminated.
Continue; minor contamination was unintentional.

title: Allowing a sick person to eat
vignette: A seriously ill woman insists on abstaining from food on Day of Atonement despite weakness. What should her family do?

options.text: Encourage her to eat small amounts to preserve health.
Respect her wish to continue abstaining from food.

title: Training children to abstaining from food
vignette: Parents debate if their twelve-year-old should attempt the full Day of Atonement period of abstaining from food this year.

options.text: Have the child practice abstaining from food part of the day only.
Expect a full period of abstaining from food like adults.

title: Replacing a lost goat for symbolic release
vignette: The designated goat for the wilderness escapes before the ceremony.

options.text: Bring a new goat and restart the random selection process.
Use another available goat without drawing random selection method again.

title: Non-member assisting with the goat for symbolic release
vignette: A non-member shepherd offers to lead the goat for symbolic release into the wilderness. May he do so?

options.text: No; only an community member may perform this service.
Allow him; the task is merely physical.

title: Aromatic Resin spilled on the floor
vignette: During the most sacred chamber service, some aromatic resin falls before being placed on the coals.

options.text: Gather it up and continue using it.
Discard it and bring new aromatic resin.

title: Confessing for others
vignette: The chief community elder recites a confession on behalf of all the homeland. Should individuals still voice personal confessions?

options.text: Yes; each person should confess privately as well.
The communal confession suffices for everyone.

title: Faded red thread on the goat for symbolic release
vignette: The crimson wool tied to the goat for symbolic release has turned pale and hardly red.

options.text: Replace it to maintain the symbol of reconciliation.
Use it as is; color doesn't affect the ritual.

title: Reconciliation without repentance
vignette: Someone assumes Day of Atonement automatically cleanses him even if he plans to repeat his misdeeds.

options.text: True repentance is required for reconciliation.
The day alone brings forgiveness regardless.

title: What to do with the leftover goat
vignette: After one of the two goats dies, what happens to the remaining one?

options.text: Leave it to graze until it gets an imperfection and sell it.
Offer it anyway to avoid waste.

title: Golden garments vs white
vignette: The chief community elder owns beautiful golden vestments and prefers wearing them instead of simple white linen.

options.text: Stick to white as prescribed for humility.
Wear the gold to inspire awe.

title: Drawing random selection method digitally
vignette: Modern community elders propose using a computer to randomize the two goats instead of a wooden box.

options.text: Adopt the new method for efficiency.
Retain the traditional random selection process box.

title: Helping a fainting faster
vignette: During the community center service, someone faints from hunger on Day of Atonement.

options.text: Give them water and food immediately.
Wait to see if they recover without feeding.
